column4: Is there a way to add hard drives in Linux so they just add to the existing filesystem, i.e. 2 x 120GB drives making a 240GB big drive?
software raid
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Software-RAID-HOWTO.html
the easiest thing, I suppose, would be to setup a raid 0 array, but the downside of that would be that if you lost one drive, you'd lose all your data.
thx for the link.

but it doesn't really matter - you can mount it wherever you want.
I frequently create a /store and mount a sceond drive to there rather than to /mnt/something
I'm surprised you've filled 120gb, though - what've you filled it with?
Thats what I'm wondering too... I have a few movies. Is there a program that can tell me this easily ?
cd / && du -h --max-depth=1
run that in a terminal without the quotes
alternatively, there are a couple of tree-based filesystem visualisers which would show you where your space is gone
df -h will tell you what partitions are mounted and what the space usage is like
Thanks, having a look
welcome.
if you want to drill down you can cd into whatever's taking up the space and run 'du -h --max-depth=1' again.
chances are most of the files are in /home or someplace like that.
or you could alter the -max-depth bit and increase the number of levels that du drills down to, but you'll probably have lots of output :)
